key_myths.title: The Tale of Zhang Lang
key_myths.summary: • The most popular origin story tells of Zhang Lang, a mortal man who abandoned his faithful wife Guo Dingxiang to marry a younger woman. His new wife was cruel and wasteful, and eventually left him. Zhang Lang became a beggar, wandering until he arrived by chance at the door of his former wife, who had remarried and prospered. She recognized him and kindly gave him food. Overcome with shame, Zhang Lang threw himself into her kitchen fire. The Jade Emperor, moved by this act of remorse, appointed him Kitchen God - condemned forever to watch over the domestic realm he had once betrayed.

key_myths.title: Alternative Origin - The Loyal Servant
key_myths.summary: • Another tradition holds that Zao Jun was originally a devoted servant who protected his master's household at the cost of his own life. The Jade Emperor rewarded his loyalty by making him protector of all households.

key_myths.title: The Jade Emperor's Spy
key_myths.summary: • Some tales describe Zao Jun as a spirit specifically created by the Jade Emperor to monitor mortal behavior. He was placed in the kitchen because it is the heart of the home, where family members gather and true natures are revealed.

key_myths.title: Zao Jun and His Wife
key_myths.summary: • Zao Jun is often depicted with his wife, Zao Jun Nainai (ç¶å›å¥¶å¥¶), who assists in observing the household. In some traditions, she softens his reports, interceding for families who show genuine effort despite their mistakes.

key_myths.title: The Sweet Bribe
key_myths.summary: • A famous story explains why sweet foods are offered to Zao Jun before his journey to heaven. One family, anxious about their misbehavior throughout the year, smeared honey on Zao Jun's lips so he would only speak sweet words to the Jade Emperor - or so his lips would stick together and he could not report at all! This custom became universal.
